body: The change looks good, would it be possible to add a test?

You can test this by running `gradle clean jarAll -x copyDependantLibs` before and after the patch. This also affects -P arguments,  -D arguments and any other [gradle command line argument](https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/gradle_command_line.html). 

Also note that that the scalaVersion property is appended in the defined tasks so when you run `gradle clean jarAll -PscalaVersion=2.11` the 2.10 and 2.11 builds will still build correctly.
LGTM. I think it is reasonable to require developers adding their own state store implementation to provide the fully initialized serdes instead of relying on the context. Merged to trunk.
@guozhangwang It might be nice to have. I think users may end up having to manage the paused set themselves anyway, but it seems natural to provide an API for more direct access.
The change LGTM. I think there may be some new usages which need to be updated when rebasing though (e.g. DefaultPartitionGrouper in Kafka Streams still depends on the null value).

@ijuma Do you mean adding it to the comments or update the ticket description? I did not test Java 1.7 CRC32 performance. I only tested the one we used to use and the CRC32 performance in Java 1.8.
LGTM. Cherrypicked to 0.9.0 as well.
@ijuma @granthenke Thank you for the reviews. I have added a note in upgrade.html.

In addition to nanotime being relative, it is also much slower (http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19052316/why-is-system-nanotime-way-slower-in-performance-than-system-currenttimemill) and more precise (but not necessarily more accurate.

Since it is much slower I suggest not having the millisecond-level relativeTime - there is no reason to pay additional performance cost for no extra precision. It is seriously misleading (and perhaps you even mislead yourself...)

Regarding whether the other names make sense, I'll defer to @ijuma who created the original JIRA.
cc @hachikuji

One other advantage of System.nanoTime is that it is monotonically increasing. With regards to the performance cost, here's a thorough and reliable analysis on the cost of `System.nanoTime`:

http://shipilev.net/blog/2014/nanotrusting-nanotime/

I was unable to find an analysis of similar quality for `System.currentTimeMilllis`. We should definitely quantify the performance difference (particularly on Linux) before we choose one way or another.

Also, it would be good to do KAFKA-2247 before we do this.
@becketqin I added a comment to the JIRA. Maybe we continue the conversation there.
Hi @guozhangwang I have created ticket : https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3181.

Quantifying the performance differences will be great, but regardless - there is an important qualitative difference - on our target OS (Linux and Windows), currentTimeMillis does not require an interrupt and nanoTime does. Interrupts are a whole different story on systems that are already running at capacity (since they cause the process to lose its place on CPU queue, which on congested systems can be a huge time sink). For this reason I think its important to avoid nanoTime when at all possible.

@gwenshap Yes, the impact on machines running at capacity is very important indeed. Aleksey covered this in the blog post above and he called it the scalability challenge. It's a shame that the blog post from David Holmes (https://blogs.oracle.com/dholmes/entry/inside_the_hotspot_vm_clocks) is from 2006 and a bit Windows-centric. It would be quite handy to have updated blog post as many things have changed since then (at all levels, CPUs, OSes, JVMs).

For Mac OS X, some numbers are available here: https://bugs.openjdk.java.net/browse/JDK-8040140?focusedCommentId=13484433&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-13484433

System.nanoTime becomes more costly than System.currentTimeMillis as the number of threads increases.
Unit test passed locally.

@guozhangwang LGTM, only a minor comment. But are we also ok with that change to the default config for `TIMESTAMP_EXTRACTOR_CLASS_CONFIG`? There didn't seem to be a conclusion to the discussion with @ymatsuda.
@ymatsuda Please let me know if you still have concerns about `TIMESTAMP_EXTRACTOR_CLASS_CONFIG`?
@ymatsuda , also remove the call to de-assign partitions since it is always de-assigned after restoration is done, so that we will not get `ConsumerClosedAlready` exception.

Ok, LGTM and there seems to be agreement on the `TIMESTAMP_EXTRACTOR_CLASS_CONFIG` default.

@becketqin Correct me if I am wrong, but it looks like we don't have integration test for the case when the broker rejects messages because the timestamp is outside of configured time difference.
I think it would be easier to track the additional tests we need to do (beyond this PR) if we created separate KAFKA JIRAs for them. Could you please create JIRAs?

LGTM

@apovzner Good catch. I am going to add the rejected message unit integration test. This actually exposed a separate bug on the server side that causing it not returning the correct error code. I create KAFKA-3189 for that bug. Will update unit integration test after that bug is fixed.

I'm not working on the project that uses Kafka on Windows any more at the moment, so if anyone else wants to run with this my patch might provide a good starting point.  I've pinged some of my old colleagues, I think they are interested in moving this along, and at some point they will probably submit a new PR with an updated patch.  If and when that happens I'll link to it here.

@ewencp Finally got the muckrake tests working and everything seems to work. One thing I noted, however, is that we might want to change WorkerSinkTask to refer to the older onPartitionsRevoked/onPartitionsAssigned methods. Otherwise, it will not be possible to use libraries compiled against older versions of the API. What do you think?
Hi @granthenke are you blocked on anything for this PR and KIP-4 in general?

Hi @guozhangwang I am not. I plan to pick up on this with near total focus in the next few days. My apologies for the delay. Other priorities got in the way. 

My plan here is to add the logic to support blocking in the server side. We will need to think through how to handle a timeout in the request. Because topic creation is fire and forget in the current implimentation. It's not "transactional" in anyway. Meaning if I block for 5 minutes and the topic is still not completely created it may get created later, unless I have some sort of undo logic. I am thinking just blocking and leaving the existing behavior as is may be a good middle ground. Especially because creation issues should be rare.
